newsitem.title: USA: Stone cuts pulp, paper output in Q2.
newsitem.headline: Stone cuts pulp, paper output in Q2.

text.p: Stone Container Corp said Friday it expects to remove at least 350,000 tons of pulp and paper production in the second quarter through market-related downtime at its pulp and paper mills.
Stone said the expected reduction in output includes 239,000 tons for inventory balancing purposes.
In the first quarter, 97,000 tons of production were removed, including 72,000 for inventory balancing.
"Demand for our core products remains strong and downtime is returning inventories to more normal levels," Roger Stone, chairman, said in a statement.

In addition, Stone-Consolidated Corp, the Canadian company in which Stone Container has a major interest, removed about 43,000 metric tonnes of newsprint and groundwood papers from production during the first quarter.

"In this improving environment, we have implemented a containerboard price increase in Europe, and recently announced a $50 per ton increase in our domestic containerboard products effective June 1," Stone said.
He added Stone Container also increased market pulp prices effective in May.
Stone-Consolidated announced a $75 per metric tonne price increase for newsprint that the company believes will be implemented fully in the second quarter.
"I am confident that the process of margin restoration has begun and will continue throughout the year," Stone said.
Looking ahead, Stone said he foresees a return to more normal market conditions as early as this summer.

Earlier today, Stone Container, a paper, paper packaging and pulp company, reported a first quarter net loss of $96.7 million or $0.99 a share, compared with a year-ago profit of $32.4 million or $0.30 per fully diluted share.
The company said that continued low selling prices for the company's core products led to the loss. It blamed industry-wide overproduction for the low prices.
